Diderot’s Life and Major Writings
1. Diderot’s Life and Major Writings

Diderot’s long, varied, and eventful life can be presented in
four distinct phases:

a period of maturation amidst struggle in the 1730s–40s as
the impoverished young Diderot sought to establish himself as a writer
in Old Regime Paris through the pursuit of the highly precarious
vocation of writing and publishing;
a period of intellectual ascent after 1749 as Diderot used the new
financial stability and intellectual notoriety acquired by editing the
Encyclopédie to build a base for his mature career as
an Enlightenment writer, critic, and philosophe;;
a period of intellectual celebrity as the new freedom brought
about by the completion of the Encyclopédie in 1765
allowed Diderot to produce some of his most important, if often
unpublished, work;
a twilight period begun in 1773 after his financial burdens were
fully eliminated through Empress Catherine the Great of Russia’s
lucrative patronage, when Diderot brought to completion the wider
philosophical program established earlier, with an additional
dimension of political radicalism.
